title: Starbucks Beats Expectations With Focus on Operations

title: Creditors Say Lampert Reaped Billions but Left Sears Insolvent
summary: Sears's creditors outline how the billionaire's hedge fund profited from stock buybacks, spinoffs and interest charges. Sears Holdings Corp. Chairman Edward Lampert and his hedge fund ESL Investments Inc. deployed stock buybacks, spinoffs and dividends to rake in billions of dollars while stripping the 126-year-old company of assets and cash, according to an investigation by the retailer's creditors.

title: U.S. to Start Returning Some Asylum Seekers to Mexico
summary: New Trump border plan to begin in San Diego 'imminently'. The Trump administration on Friday will start returning some asylum-seeking migrants to Mexico to wait for their U.S. immigration court hearings, the first step in implementing a new border policy announced last month.

title: NYC to Pay $3.3 Million to Kalief Browder's Family
summary: Lawyer representing Mr. Browder's estate called the settlement fair. New York City will pay $3.3 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the family of the teenager who spent three years at the Rikers Island jail complex after being accused of stealing a backpack, becoming a symbol of dysfunction in the criminal-justice system.

title: From Quiet Beginnings, Maduro's Challenger Raises Voice in Venezuela

A hedge fund that recently raised its stake in PG&E Corp.'s stock is pushing to oust the California utility's board of directors and says the shares, now trading around $14, could be worth more than $50 with the right corporate governance.

title: Home-Builder Stocks Bounce Back as Mortgage Rates Slide
summary: Renewed optimism has lifted home-builder shares this month, but investors remain cautious. Shares of home builders battered during 2018 have soared so far this year, an optimistic sign for the U.S. economy amid fresh worries over a stagnant housing market and slowing global growth.

title: Bristol-Myers Reports Higher Sales but Another Lung-Cancer Setback
summary: Key drugs drive sales, but company withdraws FDA application for cancer-immunotherapy combination. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. said its fourth-quarter revenue rose on sales of key drugs, and the company expects further growth this year as it works to complete the planned $74 billion acquisition of rival cancer drugmaker Celgene Corp.

title: U.S. Stocks End Day Mixed on Earnings, Trade Concerns
summary: S&P 500's consumer-staples sector weighed down by McCormick, which missed analysts' estimates. The S&P 500 eked out a small gain Thursday as investors continued to weigh corporate earnings reports, global trade tensions and concerns about slowing economic growth.

title: 'The Invisibles' Review: Those Who Remained, Resisted and Survived
summary: This docudrama follows four young Jewish Berliners who endured in the Nazi capital during World War II.. Documentaries with dramatized re-creations are an elusive genre. Can the re-created passages do justice to the factual or historical material? The answer is yes in the case of "The Invisibles," a docudrama, in subtitled German, about four young Jewish Berliners who, separated from their families, survived in the Nazi capital during World War II. The re-creations are underdramatized, whether by choice or for lack of elaborate production resources; they're most notable for their dailiness, an almost eerie state of calm that gives way only occasionally to imminent threats of betrayal, deportation or death. Yet that's an accurate reflection of on-camera interviews with the actual survivors. In old age they look back on their experiences with dismay, to be sure, but also with fascination, equanimity and a quietly thrilling fondness for an adventure that tested their mettle, as well as with gratitude for good non-Jewish Germans who helped them along the way.

title: 'The Kid Who Would Be King' Review: Some Brief, Shining Moments
summary: A modern-day, fresh-faced Arthur yanks a sword out of a stone and raises a citizen army to fight against Morgana.. In a surreal shot of an English newsstand, the front pages of the tabloids trumpet gloom and doom. Literally. One paper's headline is "Gloom," another's is "Doom." A doomy-voiced narrator laments a "divided and leaderless land" in which "men's hearts are hollow." The realm of Theresa May as Brexit nears its climax? No, the homeland of a kid named Alex (Louis Ashbourne Serkis), who, pursued by schoolyard bullies, finds a sword stuck in a stone at a construction site, yanks it out and, by the time-warped grace of Excalibur, becomes a latter-day King Arthur. It's a charming notion, worked out zestfully by the writer-director, Joe Cornish, until the charm falls victim to familiar CGI Halloweenery (hounds of hell on a rampage, a rising up of undead knights); excessive self-awareness (Alex is so steeped in Arthurian lore that he isn't all that astonished by what's happening to him); and inspirational messages about courage in the face of bullying and achieving personal nobility through selflessness.

title: América Móvil Buys Telefónica's Operations in 2 Nations
summary: Carlos Slim's Mexican telecom company pays a total of $648 million. MEXICO CITY-Mexican telecommunications company América Móvil SAB said Thursday it has bought the Guatemalan operations of Telefónica SA, and agreed to acquire the Spanish company's business in El Salvador.

title: Brazil's Justice Minister Vows to Combat Corruption
summary: The government won't stand in the way of a corruption probe involving the president's son, Moro said in an interview. Brazil's government won't stand in the way of a corruption probe involving the president's son and plans to introduce sweeping new legislation to tackle endemic graft in the country, Justice Minister Sergio Moro told The Wall Street Journal on Thursday.

title: New York Bill Would Tighten Background Checks for Private-School Employees
summary: State lawmakers' push to expand fingerprinting requirement comes amid efforts to fight sexual abuse of minors. Staff at New York private schools would have to submit fingerprints and undergo comprehensive background checks under a new child-safety measure introduced this week by state lawmakers.

title: U.S. Treasurys Rise Amid New China Trade Concerns
summary: Bond yields fall after Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross says the U.S. and China remain far from a trade deal. U.S. government bond prices rose Thursday after Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said that the U.S. and China remain far from a trade agreement.

title: 'Black Earth Rising' Review: Seeking Justice After Catastrophe
summary: Netflix's new thriller looks at the prosecutions that follow the Rwandan genocide.. It would be hard to overstate the vivid promise of "Black Earth Rising" as the series begins unfolding (Friday on Netflix)-a story of genocide, of the struggle for justice and, above all, of the pursuit of the guilty who continued to enjoy successful lives, their past crimes hidden. A tale, too, of a mother and daughter-the former, prosecutor Eve Ashby (a sterling Harriet Walter), implacably determined to seek punishment for the guilty in The Hague. The latter, Kate (Michaela Coel), a young woman now, bitterly opposed to her mother's prosecution of a man accused of a central role in the murder of hundreds of thousands-an opposition for which she can claim special knowledge.

title: 'Breslin and Hamill: Deadline Artists' Review: Blue Collars, Stained With Ink
summary: An HBO documentary captures the mood of an era through the stories of old-school New York journalists Jimmy Breslin and Pete Hamill.. 'Breslin and Hamill: Deadline Artists" comes with a heavenly supply of gossip, a treasury of revered observations on life-mainly wisecracks-and a delectably detailed view of the larger world of print journalism in which its subjects thrived. That period for these working-class journalists, as they called themselves, began in the early '60s. At the beginning of this film (Monday, 8 p.m., HBO ), one commentator, the decidedly non-working-class journalist Edward Kosner-he had, for one thing, attended college-explains how things worked. WASPs read the Herald Tribune, the Jews read the New York Post and the New York Times, and the Irish and Italians read the Daily News.

summary: It wasn't clear why the search engine had become inaccessible this week. title: Fires Highlight the Long Decline of PG&E
summary: Is PG&E the proverbial canary in the coal mine for California corporations?. Regarding ("Utility Sparked 1,500 Wildfires, Now Faces Collapse," page one, Jan. 14): One wonders whether PG&E 's disastrous performance is the proverbial canary in the coal mine for California corporations. As California corporations adapt to the new social-responsibility demands being placed on them, how many more will follow a similar path, failing to perform their primary purpose, which is to meet the demands of their customers while providing a competitive return to their investors?

title: Better Street Design Is Preventing Fatalities
summary: Since 2014, New York City traffic fatalities have declined for five years running, from 299 deaths in 2013 to 200 in 2018, bucking national trends.. Regarding Christopher LeGras's Vision Zero, a 'Road Diet' Fad, Is Proving to Be Deadly" (Cross Country, Jan. 19): Vision Zero is no "fad." It is proven and sound public policy-evidenced by New York City's results as the first American city to adopt the initiative. Since 2014, traffic fatalities here have declined for five years running, from 299 deaths in 2013 to 200 in 2018, bucking national trends.

title: A Guide to Most Wearable-and Unwearable-Men's Trends for 2019
summary: On runways showing fall clothing in London, Milan and Paris, gaudy streetwear statements at last gave way to reason. FOR ITS PRESENTATION near the end of the men's fashion shows in Paris last week, French label Jacquemus invited editors and buyers to a midmorning feast at the Palais de Tokyo art museum. Guests mingled, munching on croissants and sipping coffee. Eventually, models joined the breakfast party, marching in their pocket-heavy work coats and wool suits over to the table, where they too began eating away. The clothes felt almost beside the point, as Jacquemus gave us a meal with a message: A jacket is important, but if you can't live in it, break bread in it, then what's the point?

title: The Former Senator Who Made His Home Aboard a Historic Lightship
summary: Nautical-history lover Bill Golden transformed a Nantucket ship that once welcomed immigrants to America into a modern vessel that has hosted celebrities. In the mid-1800s, mariners navigating the New England coast dreaded the Nantucket South Shoals, an area of dangerously shallow water east of Nantucket Island. In 1854, Congress stationed Nantucket's first lightship off the coast: Its lights kept boats from coming too close, and would sometimes serve as immigrants' first glimpse of the U.S., before they reached the Statue of Liberty.

title: Lexus ES 300h: Spend on the Luxury, Save on Gas Money
summary: With a stylish exterior, a spacious cabin and a 'silky, near silent' hybrid system that gets 44 mpg, this surprising overachiever meets the demands of most drivers. Dan Neil, for once, finds few faults. AT THE OUTSET of what will be a rave review of a slow beige hybrid sedan, I feel the need to lay out my car-guy bona fides. Naturally I enjoy being strapped in the nosecone of a hypercar like the McLaren Senna atop a blooming pillar of testosterone. I believe the greatest TV show in history is Alain de Cadenet's "Victory by Design." The three classics I would choose to be marooned with on a desert isle are the Citroën DS21 Decapotable, Facel Vega HK500, and a Porsche 959 Komfort.

title: The Lunchbox Renaissance
summary: Bringing leftovers to work used to be boring, but new recipes and stylish containers have changed the game. Packed lunches are suddenly chic. I first realized this a couple of years ago in the cafeteria of the library where I do much of my research. I had brought in a bento box of food from home, and two women, both strangers, rushed up to compliment me on my lunch. I wasn't eating anything so remarkable: just some leftover pasta jazzed up with herbs, a few slices of mozzarella with olives and a portion of cold roasted carrots sprinkled with pumpkin seeds and chili flakes. But it seems that the brown bag lunch has become an object of desire.

Loose tailoring and a more grown-up approach to dressing feels modern again-a welcome change. For the more casual reader, workwear is the new way forward: Buy a pair of Carhartt pants ASAP.. title: Unenforceable Laws Against Pleasure
summary: The 100th anniversary of Prohibition is a reminder of how hard it is to regulate consumption and display. This month we mark the centennial of the ratification of the Constitution's 18th Amendment, better known as Prohibition. But the temperance movement was active for over a half-century before winning its great prize. As the novelist Anthony Trollope discovered to his regret while touring North America in 1861-2, Maine had been dry for a decade. The convivial Englishman condemned the ban: "This law, like all sumptuary laws, must fail," he wrote.

title: A Post-Holiday Bouquet Based on a Pretty, Pooped-Out Reveler
summary: Floral designer Lindsey Taylor riffs on an 1899 painting, 'Decadent Young Woman. After the Dance,' by Spaniard Ramon Casas. ON MY INSTAGRAM feed, up popped a painting by an artist unfamiliar to me: "Decadent Young Woman. After the Dance" (1899) is the work of Ramon Casas (1866-1932), a Spaniard known for portraits of the intellectual elite of Barcelona, Paris and Madrid. His portrayal of a woman succumbing to the exhaustion too much revelry brings felt appropriate as inspiration for my January, post-holiday-frenzy arrangement.

title: Aggression in Boys Is a Family Matter
summary: A new study of children shows that problematic behavior can be identified in infancy, if not before, by looking at their background and circumstances. In 25 years of clinical practice as a psychologist I've seen my share of aggressive boys. They ended up in my office because they kicked classmates, poked children with scissors or, in one unforgettable case, set another student's collar on fire to get his attention. (It worked.) These boys were usually between the ages of 4 and 10, and most of them came from chaotic homes with few clear expectations, closely spaced siblings and an overwhelmed mother. The father was often absent, literally or psychologically. They had been referred by their teachers, who wanted the aggression to stop.

title: Nissan CEO Hints He Will Step Down

title: Chef Sean Brock Will Open a Sprawling Temple to Appalachian Culture in Nashville
summary: After two years of soul-searching, the king of Lowcountry cooking returns to his roots with a shrouded new venture-and it's "the restaurant I want to retire in". He is one of the country's foremost evangelists for the roots of Southern cooking. But, until recently, Sean Brock, 40, had been neglecting his own. As a chef, he earned national acclaim elevating South Carolina's Lowcountry cuisine-at McCrady's Tavern and Husk in Charleston-but Brock was actually born and raised in Virginia's Appalachian coal country, in a mountainous wedge near the borders of Tennessee and Kentucky. As a kid he didn't realize the region's sour corn, greasy beans, pawpaws and other hand-me-down specialties constituted a cuisine. "It was just what you ate," he says.

title: Black Women Emerge as Democrats' Top Target in 2020

summary: Allegation against Yang Hengjun was also leveled against two Canadian citizens detained in December. BEIJING-China said an Australian writer who went missing while traveling in the country has been detained on suspicions of threatening state security, the same allegation leveled at two Canadian citizens detained in December.

title: Golf's New Conundrum: Flagstick In or Out?
summary: A new rule change has left golfers pondering whether leaving the flagstick in the hole might increase their likelihood of sinking putts. On a 45-degree day in late December, Lou Stagner mentioned to his wife that he was headed to a golf course near their home outside Philadelphia. He'd be gone for several hours over the next few days, he explained, as he carried a handmade, wooden ball ramp out the door and prepared for an elaborate putting simulation.

title: Southwest Airlines Beats Earnings Expectations
summary: The carrier says the government shutdown has had a negative sales impact of $10 million to $15 million thus far in January. Southwest Airlines Co. beat analysts' earnings expectations in the latest quarter, as passenger revenue increased.

title: Pope Brings Pro-Migrant Message to Central America
summary: At the start of a four-day visit to Panama, Pope Francis takes a step into the issue at the center of the U.S. government shutdown. Pope Francis defended migrants at the start of his four-day trip to Central America on Thursday, taking up a fraught issue at the heart of the U.S. government shutdown as new caravans of thousands fleeing poverty and violence take form in the region.

title: Planned Parenthood Develops Chatbot to Reach More Teens
summary: 'Roo' can answer questions about birth control, STDs and more. Planned Parenthood has developed a chatbot that can answer questions about sexual health, part of a larger communications effort by the health-services group to bring sex education to the young masses.

title: Malaysia Elects New King After Historic Abdication
summary: Sultan Abdullah of Pahang is named Malaysia's new king, replacing Sultan Muhammad who stepped down earlier this month. KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia-Malaysia's sultans chose a new king Thursday in a unique and secretive process following the unprecedented abdication of the previous monarch.

title: Bing, Baidu and a Big Mess for Chinese Search Engines
summary: Internet users are wondering why Microsoft-owned Bing is suddenly inaccessible in China. The sector faces some even bigger questions.. Is using Bing the best way to Google something in China? Not right now, at least: The U.S. search engine has suddenly become inaccessible inside the country. It's unclear whether this is just a technical glitch or something more malicious. Bing's owner Microsoft merely confirmed the site was down Thursday.

title: New York City's Nightlife Economy Is Thriving, Study Finds
summary: Restaurant and bar wage growth outpaces city overall. New York City nightlife is flourishing, with wage and employment growth outpacing that of the city's overall economy, according to a study commissioned by the Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment.

title: U.S. Contemplates Appointing First Female President of World Bank
summary: Strong woman candidate could clear away competitors. The race to select the next president of the World Bank could be shaped by a strong international desire for the institution to have its first female president.

summary: Chinese giant pushes to be a global leader in the next-generation technology despite growing Western backlash. title: AI, Machine Learning Jobs Among Highest Paid in Tech
summary: Average annual wages for these jobs AI rose to $200,000, according to a report. Artificial-intelligence and machine-learning professionals are expected to earn some of the highest salaries for information-technology jobs in the year ahead.

title: Indonesia Frees Christian Politician Convicted of Blasphemy
summary: The jailing of former Jakarta Gov. Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, once a rising political star, marked the growth of Islamist political power. JAKARTA, Indonesia-A Christian politician was freed from prison Thursday after serving most of a two-year sentence for blaspheming Islam, a case that fueled religious tensions and emboldened hard-liners in the world's largest Muslim-majority country.

title: China's Silk Road Fund Denies It Has Been in Talks With Japan Display
summary: Japanese company has been looking for a bailout because Apple's iPhone lineup has shifted away from liquid-crystal displays. TOKYO-China's state-owned Silk Road Fund denied a series of recent reports including by The Wall Street Journal that it has been in talks with struggling smartphone-screen panel maker Japan Display Inc. over a potential investment.

title: World's Biggest Brands to Test Refillable Containers
summary: P&G, Nestlé and others try to curb plastic waste; Tropicana in glass bottles, Tide in metal cans. title: China's Slowdown Is a Drag for Fuel Refiners
summary: A sagging appetite for gasoline this year could mean a flood of exports to the rest of Asia, pressuring margins. An economic slowdown will curb China's appetite for gasoline this year. That could mean a flood of exports to the rest of Asia, further pressuring regional refiners' margins.

title: Kim Jong Un Upbeat on Denuclearization After Receiving Letter From Trump
summary: Trump sent a response after receiving a letter from the North Korean leader. SEOUL-North Korean leader Kim Jong Un expressed "great satisfaction" after receiving a letter from President Trump, following the return of a nuclear envoy who traveled last week to Washington where the two sides agreed to a second summit in late February.

title: U.S. Recognizes Venezuelan Opposition Leader as Interim President
summary: National Assembly head Juan Guaidó's declaration follows demonstrations marking biggest show of opposition against Nicolás Maduro since 2017 crackdown; a challenge to Russia, China. President Trump took on Venezuela's leftist authoritarian president and his regime's Russian and Chinese backers on Wednesday by recognizing the opposition leader of the oil-rich country's congress as its legitimate head of state.

title: Wife of 'El Chapo' Coordinated His 2015 Prison Escape, Witness Says
summary: Emma Coronel relayed orders from her husband while he was in Altiplano prison, former lieutenant says. A former lieutenant of Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán testified Wednesday about the monthslong plot by the Mexican drug lord's wife and sons to help him escape from a maximum-security prison in 2015 by driving a motorcycle through a mile-long tunnel dug underneath his prison cell.

title: New York Lawmakers Pass Bill to Drop Student Test Scores From Teacher Reviews
summary: Judging educators by state exams is inaccurate, stressful and hurts students, Unions say. In a win for teachers unions, the New York Legislature overwhelmingly passed a bill Wednesday to scrap a mandate for districts to rate teachers partly by students' scores on state tests.

summary: Layoffs could affect about 250 jobs across the digital publishing company. BuzzFeed is planning to lay off about 15% of its workforce, according to people familiar with the situation, as the company seeks to reorient itself in a shifting digital-media landscape.

title: The Global Boom, Barely Begun, May Be Over
summary: Central banks need to proceed carefully: in a low-growth world, a little bit of monetary tightening can go a long, and painful, way.. DAVOS, Switzerland-A year ago the world looked like it would finally return to the boom times it enjoyed before the global financial crisis. Now, the boom may be over before it even started.

title: Revolt in Venezuela
summary: A desperate nation rises to swear in a new democratic leader.. Will this be the moment that Venezuelans finally reclaim their democracy? Millions dared to hope on Wednesday as they poured into the streets of Caracas and other cities to demand the resignation of dictator Nicolás Maduro in favor of the president of the National Assembly, 35-year-old Juan Guaidó.

title: L.A. Schools and Students Lose
summary: The union's six-day strike seems to have achieved nothing.. Los Angeles teachers called off their six-day strike on Tuesday, and it looks like everyone came out a loser-teachers, schools and students. But then this was more about political muscle-flexing than improving education.

summary: A few Republicans want to give Trump unilateral authority on tariffs.. 'We've got to have an Old Testament approach to trade-an eye for an eye." Didn't Martin Luther King Jr. say this theory "leaves everybody blind"?

title: New York City Council Kicks the Tires on Scooter-Sharing Program
summary: Transportation officials warn that adding electric scooters could pose challenges on congested streets and sidewalks. Transportation officials on Wednesday welcomed the idea of introducing an electric scooter-share program in New York City, but warned that the wheels would present a unique challenge to the nation's most populous city.

title: More U.S. Companies Separating Chief Executive and Chairman Roles
summary: The percentage of S&P 500 companies whose chief executive also was chairman reached a decade low in 2018. A push by corporate governance experts, shareholders and, in some cases, regulators to untangle the chairman and chief executive positions at U.S. public companies is gaining traction.

title: U.S. Believes It Doesn't Need to Show 'Proof' Huawei Is a Spy Threat
summary: Chairman of Chinese telecom firm contends Huawei is being unfairly targeted. The chairman of embattled telecom giant Huawei Technologies Co. is pushing back against claims his company conducts espionage for the Chinese government, contending that Huawei is being unfairly targeted without any proof. "If they believe there's a backdoor, they should offer evidence to prove it," Liang Hua told reporters on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos this week.

title: An Independent Fed Isn't 'Loco,' It's Effective
summary: Unelected technocrats are exactly the type of people you should want making monetary-policy decisions.. Who would you trust with the nation's monetary policy, Donald Trump or Jerome Powell? One is a bombastic, narcissistic former real-estate developer who thinks interest rates should always be lower than they are-unless Barack Obama is president. The other is a smart, levelheaded, not very political gentleman with substantial financial expertise and prior experience as a Federal Reserve governor.

title: Russia, Turkey Leaders Discuss Deeper Partnership in Syria
summary: Erdogan increasingly turns to Putin as the U.S. prepares to withdraw troops from northern Syria. Russia's president and his Turkish counterpart discussed Wednesday how to divide up control of northern Syria when U.S. troops leave, highlighting Washington's diminished say in Syrian affairs.

title: Where's the Mercy in 'Social Justice'?
summary: The arbitrariness and voyeurism reveal the spirit of vengeance that animates these rituals of accusation.. The news has become a viral heat map of "social justice" trials and tribulations. The swift indictment of Covington Catholic High School students on a field trip from Park Hills, Ky., to Washington is the latest example of a now routine phenomenon in which millions of strangers subject individual action (and inaction) to forensic analysis, all while gleefully condemning those they have no intention of meeting for crimes that have no discernible victims.

title: Trump's Mideast 'Deal of the Century' May Be a Raw One for Israel
summary: His plan is a closely held secret, but the signals look worrying for supporters of the Jewish state.. President Trump has spoken repeatedly about his desire to find the "deal of the century" to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. While the president's specific plan remains a tightly held secret, he and several aides occasionally drop hints about it. From what one can tell, it doesn't sound good.
